data.text: EAL/HMN 221 Introduction to Chinese Literature: Imperial and Other Romances COURSE DESCRIPTION Fall 2012 This is an introductory course in Chinese literature from the classical to the modem period. Given the mass, range, and chronological sweep of the Chinese literary tradition, this course focuses on one theme -- imperial (and other) romances. This approach enables us to incorporate fiction and poetry as well as film and TV adaptations and span the classical and modem periods. Topics of discussion include sexual and court politics, constructions of gender, and representations of love and marriage. INSTRUCTOR INFORMATION Yaohua Shi Email: shiy@wfu.edu Office hours: TTH 3:15-4:15 pm or by appointment REQUIRED TEXTS Lillian Lee, Farewell My Concubine Yang Jiang, Baptism Qian Zhongshu, Fortress Besieged Eileen Chang, Love in a Fallen City Shen Fu, Six Records of a Floating Life Li Yu, A Tower for the Summer Heat Qu Yuan, The Songs of the South HANDOUTS Poems by Yuan Zhen, Bai Juyi, and others COURSE OBJECTIVES The main objective of the course is to understand and appreciate representative works of Chinese literature through close reading, discussion, and analysis. Specific learning outcomes: Recognize and understand figurative language such as metaphors, similes, synecdoches, metonymies and so on; Recognize, understand, and apply knowledge of literary devices such as plot, characterization, point of view, setting, theme, symbols, imagery and so on; 1
